text: Good morning everybody. Thanks for being here. This is another seminar in quite a series that we have been organizing and actually I want to take the opportunity to thank Isabel for following up on the seminars. If you have any idea for your own to present or any speaker you think should come and give a seminar, you can always float the idea. Today we invited Lugdandova. Lugdandova is a very esteemed colleague which whom we have been working over the past years in a very fruitful collaboration between Simit and Simba staff. When you see some of the numbers about publications coming out of the long-term trial infrastructure, the long-term trials we have here in Mexico, part of those publications come from student collaborations that we have been doing together with Simba staff and Lugd's research team. What I always say is the uniqueness is Lugdandova has a lot of nice ideas, nice research tools that we don't have and we have the long-term trials that can actually be the background or that can generate the story through using those insights that are way more upstream than what we are doing. Lugdandova has a very long and recognized career. He started his work at the University of Leuven, then was quite some time active in Rotemstadt and finally landed in Mexico in Simba staff where he is still leading one of the most important research teams on carbon nitrogen cycling and recently micro organism processes but I'm sure he will explain that way better than I can do. So thank you and let's give a round of applause. Good morning, good morning and thanks for coming. Okay, that's the title of my talk. I mentioned at the bottom because if you read some of the earlier papers then people try to give certain characteristics to bacteria and I tried to show you that for instance they are copiotrophic, they are oligotrophic. I'm not too sure about that anymore. I think bacteria are much more flexible. I don't know if soil characteristics are important in that. It might be competition, it might be predators. I'm not sure. So this is a collaboration between different institutes, some younger researchers working in... We've already mentioned it's rather a good collaboration. I'm quite proud of it. We have now 31 published peer review manuscripts. We got 745 citations. Some of these citations come from some very important papers at Bramroad and we have an index of 14. So I'm quite pleased with this collaboration. We have quite a lot of other papers ready to submit. Okay, we know that agriculture practices affect yields and soil characteristics. We studied some of these Elbatan and Obrigon but I focus mostly pitfall in Elbatan. In soil characteristics, we have one problem in Elbatan, I mentioned it immediately. We got two replicated plots. So if you do an statistical analysis then you get problems because the variation is rather great. So often you see clear cut effects but they are not significant. So yeah, some of the problems. That's one of the commands of the last paper that we submit. Doesn't even know it is accepted but this is a command I often receive. I mean no, but I'm a bit worried about it because it returns and returns. That's why Obrigon is that if we want to get some soil samples and extract DNA, that becomes difficult and if we want to extract RNA then it's even more. Okay, we were expecting that these differences, especially organic matter, would have a large effect on carbon nitrogen immunization. This is a very simple representation of the aerobic incubation we do. We got some soil which have carbon dioxide and we measure in the soil mineral N and now recently we started to extract DNA to see what is happening there. Another command that I was not really aware of is that if you start to work with bacteria then you have non-parametric data. I've never, well, did a lot of research on soil characteristics, parametric but bacteria if you count they're non-parametric and again if you try to do some analysis then yeah, significant difference is rather difficult to obtain because non-parametric or more stringent if I can say it like that. Okay, so I said I would mention the problems we were encountering. These are some results of carbon and nitrogen immunization you see, not a lot of differences between your treatments, although you have a difference in carbon content and I compare that with Robbalk and Roppemstead where after how long was it, more than 160 years you really have a big difference in carbon immunization because your carbon content is extremely different. I just want to mention you know that maybe Jenkinson published a paper on microbiomass carbon, there's no replicator Robbalk. So if you look at the data on his original paper then there's no replicates there. Additionally he includes soil and you look at the line so but anyway I think a very important paper but I have some questions. Anyway, we didn't detect a big difference in carbon nitrogen immunization, we did some measurements also in the field, we did that quite a while ago and that was one of the problems we faced on some of his paper on carbon dioxide emissions, the nitrogen oxide emissions, the methane emissions that Review was pointing out you only have two replicates. Okay, conservation agriculture but okay you have these data, you have these differences, so what is the effect of these differences on microbial populations and this is a principle component analysis and it's a you try to get all your data on bacterial groups, you try to correlate them and whatever. So you get a separation between permanent beds and between conventional beds and what do you get in conventional beds you get copiotrophs, fresh organic material, consumer, they're degraded, they mineralize it. It's organisms that are nutrient depleted might be questionable as a word because normally it has more to do with nutrients than with organic material but also for organic material. So if there's a microbiologist and polygons using that because some people are very firm, So the agriculture practices do affect our microbial populations as I mentioned permanent beds they favor these groups which are oligotrophs that prefer nothing, this is the opposite, they prefer a nutrient rich, this should be reversed but anyway and then we have conventional beds where we get these organisms that prefer organic rich environments. Why? Because if you have conventional beds then you deal on top. Okay, sampling in 2012-2014 we'll get the same results, permanent beds preferred by oligotrophs preferred, they are favored and if you go to conventional practices, conventional, I always have questions is this for real? Do you have changes over time or my results correct? Because you always have this problem of technique and what do I mean by technique? When we did these first analysis we had clones, we had about 150 sequences of DNA and then we went to Piro which is about 100,000 sequences and now we go to Illumina and then we can talk about whatever you want 400 million, 200 million so the question is always there's an evolution between now. So what we start an experiment is here trying to solve samples over the year and we want to look at populations, we try to look at certain processes also because it's one of the critiques you can have on this work, it's very descriptive, descriptive, what this is all about, what you're really doing, what is the importance of all this and I will say we try to start with getting the techniques right and then we can start to focus on some questions we have. segments.text: Good morning everybody. Thanks for being here. This is another seminar in quite a series that we have been
organizing and actually I want to take the opportunity to thank Isabel for following up on the seminars.
If you have any idea for your own to present or any speaker you think should come and give a seminar,
you can always float the idea. Today we invited Lugdandova. Lugdandova is a very esteemed colleague
which whom we have been working over the past years in a very fruitful collaboration between
Simit and Simba staff. When you see some of the numbers about publications coming out of the
long-term trial infrastructure, the long-term trials we have here in Mexico, part of those
publications come from student collaborations that we have been doing together with Simba staff and
Lugd's research team. What I always say is the uniqueness is Lugdandova has a lot of nice ideas,
nice research tools that we don't have and we have the long-term trials that can actually
be the background or that can generate the story through using those insights that are way
more upstream than what we are doing. Lugdandova has a very long and recognized career. He started
his work at the University of Leuven, then was quite some time active in Rotemstadt
and finally landed in Mexico in Simba staff where he is still leading one of the most important
research teams on carbon nitrogen cycling and recently micro organism processes but I'm sure
he will explain that way better than I can do. So thank you and let's give a round of applause.
Good morning, good morning and thanks for coming.
Okay, that's the title of my talk. I mentioned at the bottom because if you read some of the
earlier papers then people try to give certain characteristics to bacteria and I tried to show
you that for instance they are copiotrophic, they are oligotrophic. I'm not too sure about that
anymore. I think bacteria are much more flexible. I don't know if soil characteristics are important
in that. It might be competition, it might be predators. I'm not sure. So this is a
collaboration between different institutes, some younger researchers working in...
We've already mentioned it's rather a good collaboration. I'm quite proud of it.
We have now 31 published peer review manuscripts. We got 745 citations. Some of these citations come
from some very important papers at Bramroad and we have an index of 14. So I'm quite pleased
with this collaboration. We have quite a lot of other papers ready to submit. Okay,
we know that agriculture practices affect yields and soil characteristics. We studied some of these
Elbatan and Obrigon but I focus mostly pitfall in Elbatan.
In soil characteristics, we have one problem in Elbatan, I mentioned it immediately. We got two
replicated plots. So if you do an statistical analysis then you get problems because the
variation is rather great. So often you see clear cut effects but they are not significant.
So yeah, some of the problems. That's one of the commands of the last paper that we submit.
Doesn't even know it is accepted but this is a command I often receive. I mean no,
but I'm a bit worried about it because it returns and returns. That's why
Obrigon is that if we want to get some soil samples and extract DNA, that becomes difficult
and if we want to extract RNA then it's even more. Okay, we were expecting that these differences,
especially organic matter, would have a large effect on carbon nitrogen immunization. This
is a very simple representation of the aerobic incubation we do. We got some soil which have
carbon dioxide and we measure in the soil mineral N and now recently we started to extract DNA to see
what is happening there. Another command that I was not really aware of is that if you start to

soil characteristics, parametric but bacteria if you count they're non-parametric and again if you
try to do some analysis then yeah, significant difference is rather difficult to obtain because
non-parametric or more stringent if I can say it like that. Okay, so I said I would mention the
problems we were encountering. These are some results of carbon and nitrogen immunization you see,
not a lot of differences between your treatments, although you have a difference in carbon content
and I compare that with Robbalk and Roppemstead where after how long was it, more than 160 years
you really have a big difference in carbon immunization because your carbon content

microbiomass carbon, there's no replicator Robbalk. So if you look at the data on his original paper

so but anyway I think a very important paper but I have some questions. Anyway, we didn't detect

we did that quite a while ago and that was one of the problems we faced on some of his paper
on carbon dioxide emissions, the nitrogen oxide emissions, the methane emissions that
Review was pointing out you only have two replicates. Okay, conservation agriculture
but okay you have these data, you have these differences, so what is the effect of these

separation between permanent beds and between conventional beds and what do you get in

they mineralize it. It's organisms that are
nutrient depleted might be questionable as a word because normally it has more to do
with nutrients than with organic material but also for organic material. So if there's a
microbiologist and polygons using that because some people are very firm,
So the agriculture practices do affect our microbial populations as I mentioned permanent
beds they favor these groups which are oligotrophs that prefer nothing, this is the opposite,
they prefer a nutrient rich, this should be reversed but anyway and then we have conventional beds
where we get these organisms that prefer organic rich environments. Why? Because if you have
conventional beds then you deal on top. Okay, sampling in 2012-2014 we'll get the same results,
permanent beds preferred by oligotrophs preferred, they are favored and if you go to
conventional practices, conventional, I always have questions is this for real? Do you have changes
over time or my results correct? Because you always have this problem of technique and what do
I mean by technique? When we did these first analysis we had clones, we had about 150 sequences of
DNA and then we went to Piro which is about 100,000 sequences and now we go to Illumina and then we
can talk about whatever you want 400 million, 200 million so the question is always there's an
